questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with back ache, morning stiffness and reddening of eyes. X-ray of the patient is given below. Identify the diagnosis of this patient: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • It also have a variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.
  • Joints Involved:
    • Primarily affects axial skeleton.
    • The disease usually begins in the sacroiliac joints and usually extends upwards to involve the lumbar, thoracic, and often cervical spine.
    • Hip joint is the most commonly affected peripheral joint.
    • Rarely, knee and ankle are also involved.
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, associated with low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • Anterior uveitis: Most common (30%) extra-articular manifestation.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
         
  • Spine Radiograph Findings:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

 

  • Later on, SI joint show irregular subchondral erosions, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
  • Calcification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacro-tuberous ligament.

 

 

Dagger sign (ossification along supraspinous & interspinous ligaments)

 

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons and ligaments.
  • Trolley/tram track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and syndesmophytes are seen. Bamboo spine appearance is due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

A. Trolley track sign (ossification along supraspinous ligaments and facet joints;

B. Bamboo spine

 

  • MRI is the most sensitive examination for sacroiliitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. In rheumatoid arthritis, upper cervical spine & hip joint are less commonly involved. There is atlantoaxial joint subluxation when cervical spine is involved. Lumbar spine is usually spared. The chronic inflammatory synovitis in the cervical spine results in severity that progresses to bone erosion and ligamentous laxity, leading to late spinal instability. The most common radiological presentations of spinal involvement in RA are: atlantoaxial subluxation, cranial settling (also known as basilar impression, atlantoaxial impaction or superior migration of the odontoid, the most severe form of spinal instability in RA), subaxial subluxation or a combination of them.

 

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthritis. In the involvement of spine & pelvis in psoriatic arthritis, the patient experiences extreme back/neck pain, stiffness in back/neck that improves on moving around. The stiffness worsens by a period of rest. There is difficulty in bending or moving the back. The patient also complaints of fatigue. The x-ray shows asymmetric paravertebral ossification, thicker & larger syndesmophytes than ankylosing spondylitis. Occasionally, there are incomplete non-marginal syndesmophytes similar to AS.

 

 

Option D. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. Etiology is genetic infection by paramyxovirus (measles and respiratory syncytial virus). There is increased bone resorption accompanied by accelerated bone formation. Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. Affects men > 50 years more commonly. Pain is most common presenting symptom. The spine is the second most commonly affected site (53%), after the pelvis (70%). The lumbar spine and more commonly the L4 and L5 levels are the most frequently involved sites. Involvement of the atlanto-axial region is very rare. The vertebral body is almost always involved with a portion of the neural arch. The radiological appearance is characterised by an increase in the antero-posterior and lateral vertebral dimensions. The height of the vertebra is unchanged. The vertebral end-plates are subchondral condensations of trabecular bone and do not represent true bony cortex, i.e. there is no periosteum/endosteum interface at the caudal/cranial aspect of a normal vertebra. The “early” radiographic appearance of vertebral body is thickening and hypertrophy of the trabecular bone, parallel to the end plates. Progression of the sclerotic phase in the spine leads to “ivory vertebra”, due to an increase in the density of the vertebral body.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The described symptoms of back ache, morning stiffness and reddening of eyes, along with the bamboo spine appearance in the spine x-ray are diagnostic of ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: In which of the following reflexes, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Enterogastric

 

Explanation

 

Enterogastric reflex is the reflex that inhibits gastric emptying. It is elicited by the presence of chyme in the duodenum, which prevents further emptying of stomach.

 

Mechanism of enterogastric reflex

 

  1. Presence of chyme in duodenum causes generation of nerve impulses which are transmitted to stomach by the intrinsic nerve fibers of GI tract. After reaching the stomach, these impulses inhibit emptying.
  2. Impulses from duodenum pass via extrinsic sympathetic fibers to stomach and inhibit emptying.
  3. Some impulses from duodenum travel through afferent vagal fibers to the brainstem. Normally, brainstem neurons send excitatory impulses to stomach through efferent vagal fibers and stimulate gastric emptying. However, the impulses from duodenum inhibit these brainstem neurons and thereby inhibit gastric emptying.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrocolic Reflex: Incorrect. The gastrocolic reflex triggers increased colonic motility in response to food entering the stomach. It does not directly affect gastric emptying.

 

Option B. Enterocolic Reflex: Incorrect. This is not a widely recognized reflex within standard physiological texts; it does not pertain specifically to the control of gastric emptying.

 

Option C. Gastroileal Reflex: Incorrect. The gastroileal reflex stimulates the movement of chyme from the ileum into the large intestine following food intake, which is unrelated to the initial inhibition of gastric emptying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enterogastric reflex plays a critical role in regulating the rate at which the stomach empties its contents into the duodenum, particularly under conditions where the chyme is highly acidic. This regulation ensures that the duodenum can adequately process the chyme without being overwhelmed, which is crucial for maintaining digestive health and preventing duodenal irritation or damage.

 

Factors which initiate enterogastric reflex

 

  1. Duodenal distension
  2. Irritation of the duodenal mucosa
  3. Acidity of the chyme
  4. Osmolality of the chyme
  5. Breakdown products of proteins and fats

choices.text: Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes

questions.text: A 10-year-old presents with edema and anasarca. A diagnosis of minimal change disease is made. Which of the following is true about this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Good response to steroids

 

Minimal change disease (MCD) is a type of glomerulonephritis that typically affects children and is characterized by the presence of nephrotic syndrome. The following statement is true about this condition:

 

  • Good response to steroids: MCD is often considered to be the most steroid-responsive form of nephrotic syndrome. The vast majority of children with MCD respond well to treatment with corticosteroids, with complete remission of proteinuria and edema occurring in over 90% of cases. However, the response to steroids may be less predictable in adults with MCD.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes: Electron microscopy shows nonspecific obliteration of epithelial foot processes (not light microscopy)

 

Option C. Most common in adults: it is common in pediatric age group, not adults

 

Option D. Non-selective proteinuria: the patient will have massive nephrotic range proteinuria.

 

The causes of MCD are mostly idiopathic. It is usually associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma (due to the increased production of cytokines), respiratory infections, prophylactic immunizations, eczema, and rhinitis.

 

 

Clinically, they mostly present with proteinuria. The child presents with a history of edema that is initially noted around the eyes and gradually progresses into generalized edema. Hypertension and hematuria are uncommon.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and has a very good response to corticosteroid treatment, resulting in complete remission of proteinuria and edema in over 90% of cases.

questions.text: A 53-year-old gentleman presents with chest pain which is happening at rest. Pain is persistent for 3-5 minutes and he is having recurrent pain over the last 48 hours and he used 3 puffs of GTN to relieve his pain. His current medications include GTN PRN, Atorvastatin 20mg HS, Metoprolol 50mg BID, and Aspirin 75mg OD. His troponin was negative and ECG showed LVH with flattening of the ST segment. What is the most appropriate next step in management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Start enoxaparin 1mg/kg s.c BD

 

The patient is presenting with symptoms suggestive of unstable angina, given the recurrent chest pain at rest and ECG changes (left ventricular hypertrophy with ST segment flattening). Despite the negative troponin, which rules out myocardial infarction, the clinical scenario points to a high risk of acute coronary syndrome (ACS).

 

For high-risk ACS, especially in a patient already on medications for coronary artery disease (CAD) like aspirin, atorvastatin, and metoprolol, initiating anticoagulation therapy is crucial to prevent thrombus formation and progression to myocardial infarction. Enoxaparin, a low molecular weight heparin, is recommended at a therapeutic dose of 1 mg/kg subcutaneously twice a day to achieve effective anticoagulation in this setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Add long-acting nitrate: While long-acting nitrates can help with angina symptoms, they are not the primary treatment for acute management in this scenario. The priority is to stabilize the patient and prevent further thrombotic events.

 

Option B. Increase metoprolol dose to 100mg BID: Increasing the dose of metoprolol may help with angina control, but it does not address the underlying risk of thrombus formation and is not the immediate next step in managing high-risk unstable angina.

 

Option C. Add clopidogrel 75mg OD: Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent that is beneficial in ACS, but in this acute setting, starting anticoagulation with enoxaparin takes precedence to prevent thrombus formation. Clopidogrel can be added as part of dual antiplatelet therapy later on.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with high-risk unstable angina, especially those with recurrent chest pain at rest and ECG changes, initiating therapeutic anticoagulation with enoxaparin is a critical step in the acute management to prevent thrombus formation and progression to myocardial infarction.

questions.text: A patient is planned to undergo hysteroscopic polypectomy using bipolar electrocautery. What is the ideal agent for distention? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Normal saline

 

 Explanation:

 

  • In bipolar cautery, electricity has to be conducted from one electrode to the other. So normal saline is preferably used.
  • If a monopolar resectoscope is used, then a non-electrolyte solution like glycine is required.

 

Fluid media in Hysteroscopy:

 

The following distension media can be used in hysteroscopy

 

  • CO2: Good for diagnostic procedures but not for operative hysteroscopy
  • Normal Saline
    • Not to be used with monopolar electrocoagulation
    • Good for minor procedures using bipolar instruments/ office procedures as there is very less risk of electrolyte imbalance
  • Dextran 70
    • Useful in patients with bleeding as it does not mix with blood
    • Can cause anaphylaxis, electrolyte imbalance ans fluid overload
  • Low viscosity, nonconductive fluids like: 1.5% Glycine, 3% sorbitol and 5% mannitol
    • Used in operative hysteroscopy using monopolar resectoscopes
    • Safe as there is no electrolytes to disperse the current and impede the electrosurgical effect
    • Associated with electrolyte disturbances and fluid overload

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal saline is the ideal distention medium for hysteroscopic procedures using bipolar electrocautery due to its suitability in conducting electricity between electrodes without causing significant electrolyte imbalance.

 

Ref: Page no 793, Novaks Gynecology 15th edition

questions.text: Deoxygenated blood is returned to the placenta from the fetus through? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Umbilical artery

 

Explanation:

 

Fetal circulation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Umbilical vein: Carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus, not deoxygenated blood.

 

Option C. Ductus arteriosus: Shunts blood from the pulmonary artery to the aorta in fetal circulation, bypassing the lungs. It does not return deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Option D. Ductus venosus: Shunts blood from the umbilical vein to the IVC, allowing oxygenated blood to bypass the liver. It does not return deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deoxygenated blood exits the fetus through the umbilical arteries, which return it to the placenta.

 

Ref: Page no 343, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A patient presents with a slowly progressive swelling that has been noticeable for the past 18 months. The swelling exhibits variable consistency, with some areas feeling hard and others feeling soft, image of patient is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis for this clinical presentation? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pleomorphic adenoma

 

Explanation:

 

The case scenario and image showing a swelling lifting the ear lobe are suggestive of a pleomorphic adenoma. Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common benign tumors of the salivary glands, with the parotid gland being the most frequent site. These tumors are encapsulated and exhibit a mixed cellular composition, leading to a variable consistency, which is reflected in their name "pleomorphic." Clinically, they present as painless, slow-growing masses. The characteristic lift of the earlobe due to the swelling is a classic sign of a parotid gland tumor. Untreated pleomorphic adenomas may undergo malignant transformation, hence surgical excision is typically recommended.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Jaw Tumor: Jaw tumors, particularly those of the mandible or maxilla, are often bony growths or related to the teeth (odontogenic tumors). While they can cause facial asymmetry, they are usually centered around the bones and are not typically located in the parotid gland region. These tumors tend to be hard and lack the variable consistency described in the clinical presentation.

 

Option B. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts are benign cystic tumors containing skin appendages (such as hair follicles), and sometimes hair, teeth, or sebum. They are typically congenital and found on the face, neck, or ovary. While they can appear on the face or neck, the described clinical presentation is less suggestive of a dermoid cyst compared to a pleomorphic adenoma. Dermoid cysts often show indentation due to putty material.

 

Option D. Sebaceous cyst: Also known as an epidermal cyst, a sebaceous cyst is a benign growth arising from blocked sebaceous glands, often containing a thick, cheese-like material. Sebaceous cysts can appear almost anywhere on the body where sebaceous glands are found, including the face, and often show a black punctum. However, the described clinical presentation and duration better match a pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the salivary glands, typically presenting as a painless, slow-growing mass with variable consistency and often lifting the earlobe due to its location in the parotid gland.

questions.text: A child was brought with pedal edema and cheilosis. Further investigations revealed cardiomegaly. What is the vitamin deficiency associated with this clinical presentation?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine

 

The given clinical presentation with pedal edema and cardiomegaly is suggestive of wet beriberi, which is a consequence of thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Thiamine deficiency, also known as beriberi, is a more likely candidate. Thiamine deficiency can manifest as cardiac beriberi, leading to an enlarged heart (cardiomegaly), which aligns with the clinical findings. Thiamine deficiency can also cause peripheral edema, such as pedal edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Riboflavin deficiency can lead to cheilosis, which is consistent with one of the symptoms observed. However, it is not typically associated with pedal edema or cardiomegaly.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Pyridoxine deficiency is not commonly associated with pedal edema, cheilosis, or cardiomegaly.

 

Option D. Niacin (Vitamin B3): Niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which includes symptoms like dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. It is not typically associated with cardiomegaly or pedal edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B1 deficiency disorders

questions.text: An old lady complains of chronic backpain since a few months. X-ray is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoporosis

 

The image shows Codfish Vertebra seen in Osteoporosis.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration. So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.

 

Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

Imaging

 

  • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.
  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.

 

Treatment:

 

Drugs used in osteoporosis are:

 

  1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
  2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
  3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spondylolysis: Incorrect, as spondylolysis refers to a defect or fracture of the pars interarticularis of the vertebrae, not typically associated with the changes seen in the X-ray provided.

 

Option C. Spondylolisthesis: Incorrect, this condition involves the forward slippage of one vertebra over the one beneath it, which would show distinct alignment changes not described in the X-ray findings.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis: Incorrect, as osteopetrosis is a condition characterized by the abnormal density and sclerosis of bone, quite the opposite of what is observed in osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteoporosis is a condition marked by a decrease in bone density and mass, leading to structural weakening of the bone and increased risk of fractures. Diagnostic imaging such as X-rays can show characteristic changes like "Codfish Vertebra" and is further confirmed by measuring bone mineral density through a DEXA scan. Treatment focuses on inhibiting bone resorption and/or stimulating bone formation through various pharmacological agents.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with overfamiliarity, flight of ideas, elevated mood, increased sexual desire, and pseudo hallucination. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mania

 

The patient's symptoms of overfamiliarity, flight of ideas, elevated mood, increased sexual desire, and pseudo hallucination are indicative of a manic episode. Mania is characterized by an elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, lasting at least one week, associated with increased energy or activity, and causing significant impairment in social or occupational functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypomania: Similar to mania but the symptoms are milder, last for at least 4 days, and don't significantly impair social or occupational functioning.

 

Option C. Cyclothymia: A mood disorder characterized by periods of hypomanic symptoms and periods of depressive symptoms that don't meet the full criteria for a manic or major depressive episode.

 

Option D. Schizomania: This term is not standard in psychiatric diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mania is characterized by an elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, lasting at least one week, associated with increased energy or activity, and causing significant impairment in social or occupational functioning.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 365

choices.text: Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water
Continuous exposure to cement and concrete
Continuous exposure to drills and machines

questions.text: A construction worker came to the OPD complaining of white fingers. He has been working in the cement and concrete industry and has been working on heavy machinery drills, wood, and furniture polishing for 20 years. What is the most likely etiology for this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continuous exposure to drills and machines

 

  • The white fingers suggest the diagnosis of Raynaud's syndrome, which is commonly seen in individuals exposed to vibrating tools like drills and machines.
  •  Raynaud phenomenon is characterized by decreased blood flow to the skin due to arteriolar vasospasm in response to cold or stress.
  • This condition leads to color changes in the skin, transitioning from white (ischemia) to blue (hypoxia) to red (reperfusion).

 

Raynaud's Syndrome:

 

  • Pathophysiology: Arteriolar vasospasm causes decreased blood flow.
  • Triggers: Cold or stress.
  • Symptoms: Color changes in the fingers, pain, and numbness.
  • Risk Factors: Chronic use of vibrating tools (e.g., drills, jackhammers).
  • Types:
    • Primary (Idiopathic): No associated medical condition.
    • Secondary: Associated with connective tissue diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), CREST syndrome (a form of systemic sclerosis), or mixed connective tissue disease. Digital ulceration (critical ischemia) is seen in secondary Raynaud's syndrome.
  • Treatment: Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine) to reduce the frequency and severity of vasospastic episodes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water: Candidal infections usually cause red, itchy, and swollen skin, often with pustules and a whitish coating. They do not present as white, ischemic fingers typical of Raynaud's syndrome.

 

Option B. Exposure to thinners and paints: While exposure to thinners and paints can cause dermatitis and other skin conditions, they do not typically result in the vasospastic changes seen in Raynaud's phenomenon.

 

Option C. Continuous exposure to cement and concrete: Continuous exposure to cement and concrete can cause contact dermatitis and other dermatological issues but is not associated with the vasospasm and color changes characteristic of Raynaud's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Raynaud's syndrome is characterized by episodic vasospastic attacks in response to cold or stress, leading to color changes in the fingers.
  •  Chronic exposure to vibrating tools, such as drills and machines, is a common occupational risk factor for developing this condition.
  • Treatment includes the use of calcium channel blockers to manage symptoms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive male came with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He has skin lesions as shown in the image. Chest x-ray showed multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates. His sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis was negative and he has a low CD4 count. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. HIV with disseminated histoplasmosis

 

In this case, the patient presents with persistent cough, weight loss, and skin lesions. The chest x-ray reveals multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates, and the patient has a low CD4 count. These findings are significant for several reasons:

 

Disseminated histoplasmosis can mimic tuberculosis, especially in HIV-positive patients. It causes disseminated disease with pulmonary involvement (multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates) and skin lesions. The presence of these lesions and a negative sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis further supports histoplasmosis, as this fungal infection is common in immunocompromised individuals with low CD4 counts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HIV with disseminated cryptococcosis: While cryptococcosis can cause lung disease, it more commonly presents with central nervous system involvement, such as meningitis or meningoencephalitis. This patient does not exhibit neurological symptoms, making cryptococcosis less likely.

 

Option C. HIV with molluscum contagiosum: Molluscum contagiosum causes umbilicated papules but does not lead to bilateral nodular infiltrates in the lungs. Thus, this diagnosis is unlikely given the chest x-ray findings.

 

Option D. HIV with tuberculosis: Tuberculosis is a common infection in HIV-positive patients and can present with similar symptoms and radiographic findings. However, the negative sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Disseminated histoplasmosis in HIV-positive patients can mimic tuberculosis, presenting with pulmonary nodular infiltrates and skin lesions, especially in those with low CD4 counts.

questions.text: A medical student presented with complaints of repeated episodes lasting approximately 30 minutes, characterized by breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation, and a fear of an impending heart attack. The patient has experienced these episodes 5-6 times per month over the last 6 months, and investigations did not reveal any obvious abnormalities. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Panic Disorder

 

The clinical presentation of a medical student with repeated episodes of breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation, and fear of an impending heart attack, each lasting approximately 30 minutes and occurring 5-6 times per month over the last 6 months, with no abnormalities found in investigations, is highly suggestive of Panic Disorder. Panic Disorder is characterized by recurrent, unexpected panic attacks, which are abrupt surges of intense fear or discomfort reaching a peak within minutes. The symptoms described, including palpitations, sweating, and hyperventilation, are common during panic attacks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD): GAD is characterized by persistent and excessive worry about various things, but it does not typically involve the acute, intense episodes of fear or the physical symptoms of a panic attack.

 

Option C. Depression: While depression can have anxiety symptoms and panic attacks, the primary feature is a persistent low mood and loss of interest or pleasure in activities, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option D. Social Phobia: Also known as social anxiety disorder, this involves a significant fear of social or performance situations. The symptoms described do not specifically relate to social or performance situations, making this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with anticipatory anxiety. Patients may start ‘avoiding’ situations that they link with the panic attack. Treatment includes a combination of pharmacotherapy [benzodiazepines for short term and SSRIs for long term] and psychotherapy [CBT, relaxation techniques] is preferred.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 402.

questions.text: Pseudo P pulmonale is seen in which electrolyte abnormality? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

 

Pseudo P pulmonale, characterized by exaggerated amplitude in the P wave, can be observed on an ECG in the context of hypokalemia. This electrolyte disturbance affects cardiac electrophysiology, leading to various changes including prolonged QT interval, presence of U waves, T wave flattening or inversion, and sometimes pseudo-infarction patterns, which can mimic myocardial infarction.

 

Hypokalemia can result in these distinct ECG changes due to its influence on cellular membrane potentials in cardiac cells, which alters the normal propagation of electrical impulses through the myocardium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyponatremia: Does not typically cause prominent P wave changes; its ECG manifestations are less specific and often involve general effects on conduction and contractility.

 

Note - Hyponatremia is usually silent on the ECG

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Associated with prolonged QT interval due to an elongation of the ST segment but not with pseudo P pulmonale.

 

Option D. Hypercalcemia: Typically presents with a shortened QT interval and shortened ST segment, differing significantly from the changes seen in hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A woman presents to you with fever, arthralgia, ulcers, fatigue for the past six months, and new-onset hematuria. Urine examination reveals RBC casts and proteinuria. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lupus nephritis

 

Lupus nephritis is a common complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organ systems. The patient's symptoms of fever, arthralgia, ulcers, and fatigue, combined with new-onset hematuria and findings of RBC casts and proteinuria in the urine, are indicative of systemic involvement typical of lupus nephritis.

 

Lupus nephritis is characterized by inflammation of the kidneys, often leading to hematuria, proteinuria, and renal impairment.

 

Next Step -

 

Conducting an ANA (antinuclear antibody) test.

 

Performing an anti-dsDNA (anti-double stranded DNA) test, which is noted as being very specific and correlates with lupus nephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute interstitial nephritis: This condition typically presents with WBC casts rather than RBC casts in the urine and is not usually associated with systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, or ulcers.

 

Option B. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN): While PSGN can cause RBC casts and proteinuria, it is generally a renal-limited condition and does not present with systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, and ulcers.

 

Option D. IgA nephropathy: IgA nephropathy is also a renal-limited condition and typically does not present with systemic symptoms. It is characterized by recurrent episodes of gross hematuria, usually following upper respiratory infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus nephritis should be suspected in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus who present with renal symptoms such as hematuria and proteinuria, especially when accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, ulcers, and fatigue. Further testing, including ANA and anti-dsDNA antibodies, is warranted to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Earache

 

Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

 

Tuberculosis of the ear

 

  •  Aetiology - Secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.
  •  Pathology - The process is slow and insidious. Tubercles appear in the submucosal layers of middle ear cleft and caseate. There is painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane. Multiple perforations may form which coalesce to form a single large perforation. Middle ear and mastoid get filled with pale granulations.
  • Clinical features - Painless foul smelling ear discharge, multiple perforations, hearing loss. Mastoiditis, facial paralysis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis with formation of bony sequestra are often seen in these cases.
  •  Treatment - Antitubercular treatment + Mastoidectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple perforations - A characteristic feature of the disease, representing advanced tissue damage.

 

Option C. Pale granulation - These are typical findings within the affected structures.

 

Option D. Foul smelling ear discharge - A hallmark symptom of tubercular otitis media due to the extensive necrosis and infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: An antiemetic was given to a chemotherapy patient, who then developed symptoms such as acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. Which of the following medications would have resulted in these symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metoclopramide

 

  • Metoclopramide is an antiemetic and a prokinetic drug that acts by blocking the D2 receptors. It can be given IV and it can cross the Blood brain barrier, thereby leading to D2 receptor block in the brain which can have side effects like acute dystonia, abnormal movements and drug induced Parkinsonism.
  • In such cases, to treat them, drugs having central anticholinergic action like Benzhexol are used. They work by resorting the balance that has been disrupted by having a relative cholinergic excess in the striatum due to dopaminergic blockade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ondansetron: Ondansetron is a serotonin 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. It is commonly used as an antiemetic, especially in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, but it does not cause extrapyramidal side effects like metoclopramide. Its side effect profile mainly includes headaches, constipation, and QT prolongation.

 

Option C. Meclizine: Meclizine is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties, used primarily to treat motion sickness and vertigo. It does not block dopamine receptors and therefore does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option D. Scopolamine: Scopolamine is an anticholinergic drug used to prevent nausea and vomiting, particularly motion sickness. It works by blocking acetylcholine receptors and does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms. Its side effects include dry mouth, dizziness, and blurred vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metoclopramide, an antiemetic that acts by blocking D2 receptors, can cause extrapyramidal symptoms such as acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presented with arthritis. She had a history of fever and sore throat 1 week ago. On examination, you hear a pansystolic murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation. What is the finding you will see in the biopsy? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aschoff nodule

 

The clinical presentation suggests acute rheumatic fever (ARF), a sequela of untreated or poorly treated streptococcal pharyngitis. ARF can manifest with migratory arthritis, carditis (evidenced by the pansystolic murmur indicative of mitral regurgitation), and other systemic symptoms.

 

Aschoff nodules, or Aschoff bodies, are pathognomonic for acute rheumatic fever. These are areas of fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by chronic inflammatory cells, including Anitschkow cells (macrophages with characteristic wavy nuclei). They are found in the heart tissue, especially in the myocardium, and are a hallmark of rheumatic carditis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudomyxoma: Pseudomyxoma peritonei is a condition characterized by the accumulation of mucinous material in the peritoneal cavity, typically originating from a mucinous tumor. It is not related to acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Caseating granuloma: Caseating granulomas are characteristic of tuberculosis and certain fungal infections. They consist of a central area of necrosis surrounded by a rim of activated macrophages and lymphocytes. This finding is not associated with rheumatic fever.

 

Option D. Verrucous tumour: Verrucous tumors are typically warty growths and are not related to rheumatic fever. They can be associated with certain types of skin cancers or infectious warts but have no connection to the condition described in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of sore throat followed by symptoms such as arthritis and carditis, acute rheumatic fever should be considered. The presence of Aschoff nodules in biopsy is pathognomonic for this condition, confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complains of a creepy crawling sensation in her legs. It is more at night and prevents her from sleeping. She is relieved of these symptoms by either walking or moving her legs. Which of the following drugs is used in treating the condition?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gabapentin

 

The symptoms described by the patient are consistent with restless legs syndrome (RLS). Gabapentin, and pregabalin, belong to the alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands and have now become the preferred first-line treatments for many patients with RLS due to their effectiveness and good side effect profile.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Pramipexole: Pramipexole and other dopamine agonists were traditionally first-line agents but can have side effects, including augmentation (worsening of RLS symptoms over time with treatment), which makes them less favorable for long-term management.

 

Option C. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 is not a standard treatment for RLS.

 

Option D. Iron tablets: Iron tablets may be prescribed if a patient has iron-deficiency anemia, which can exacerbate RLS symptoms. However, they are not the primary treatment for RLS unless this condition is present.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS) is a sensorimotor disorder characterized by an unpleasant sensation in the legs and an urge to move them, especially at night. It can disrupt sleep and may have secondary causes like iron deficiency. Alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands, such as gabapentin and pregabalin, are first-line treatments.

 

Reference: The Management of Restless Legs Syndrome: An Updated Algorithm Silber, Michael H.Earley, Christopher J. et al. Mayo Clinic Proceedings, Volume 96, Issue 7, 1921 - 1937.

questions.text: A middle aged man from West Bengal presents with paraesthesia of hands and feet, hyperkeratosis, lines in the nails and rain drop pigmentation in the hands. The most likely causative toxin for the above mentioned symptoms is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arsenic

 

The symptoms mentioned in the question are classic features of chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Chronic Arsenic poisoning: It is insidious in nature. The onset of symptoms usually  occurs  after 2–8  weeks of exposure.  Chronic  poisoning  may  occur among persons engaged in smelting and refining of ores and in the subliming of arsenic in the manufacture of weed killers, dyes etc.

 

Clinical Features of Chronic Arsenic poisoning:

 

  1. GIT symptoms: loss of weight, malaise, loss of appetite, salivation, colicky pain, diarrhoea and vomiting.
  2. Liver: Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis
  3. Skin symptoms: usually begin with a persistent erythematous flush leading to hyperkeratotic skin and desquamation. Hyperkeratosis is most prominent in the distal parts of the body. Pigmentation is patchy (‘raindrops pigmentation). Skin cancer (Squamous cell carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma) also occurs.
  4. Nails: Aldrich Mees lines (transverse  white  striae  of  the fingernails) may also be seen.
  5. Hairs: Alopecia occurs
  6. Hematological: Anemia, leukopenia, Thrombocytopenia and Bone marrow hypoplasia are  seen.  Anemia is normocytic and normochromic
  7.  Peripheral neuropathy: Sensory  and  motor  polyneuritis (sensory  symptoms  usually  predominate)  manifesting  as numbness and tingling in a ‘stocking glove’ distribution.
  8. Blackfoot disease: Due to platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries.
  9. Encephalopathy
  10. Nephritis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lead: Symptoms Abdominal pain, anemia, neurological deficits, but not specifically hyperkeratosis, Mees lines, or raindrop pigmentation.

 

Option C. Thallium: Symptoms Gastrointestinal disturbances, alopecia, peripheral neuropathy, but lacks the specific skin changes and nail lines associated with arsenic.

 

Option D. Mercury: Symptoms: Tremors, memory loss, gingivitis, and neurological symptoms, but does not cause hyperkeratosis or Mees lines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic arsenic poisoning presents with distinctive symptoms such as paraesthesia, hyperkeratosis, Aldrich Mees lines, and raindrop pigmentation, making it the most likely cause of the described symptoms.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common presentation of postpartum nerve injury? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Foot drop

 

Explanation:

 

The most common postpartum nerve injury is an injury to the peroneal nerve, which results in foot drop. This type of injury often occurs during deliveries where the lithotomy position is used for an extended period. The lithotomy position can cause prolonged pressure on the peroneal nerve, which is located near the fibular head, leading to nerve damage.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Peroneal nerve injury: The peroneal nerve is susceptible to compression, especially when the legs are positioned in stirrups for prolonged periods, as is common in the lithotomy position during childbirth.
  • Foot drop: This condition is characterized by an inability to dorsiflex the foot, leading to a dragging foot while walking.
  • Symptoms: Patients may present with weakness in lifting the front part of the foot and toes, a high-stepping gait to prevent the foot from dragging, and numbness or tingling over the top of the foot and the outer part of the upper leg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial palsy: This is not commonly associated with postpartum nerve injuries.

 

Option B. Wrist drop: This condition results from a radial nerve injury and is not a common presentation of postpartum nerve injuries.

 

Option D. Claw hand: This is associated with ulnar nerve injury and is also not a common presentation of postpartum nerve injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common postpartum nerve injury is peroneal nerve injury, leading to foot drop, often associated with the lithotomy position used during childbirth.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with visual disturbances. An MRI reveals a lesion at the location marked in the image. Which of the following visual field defects is most likely associated with this lesion? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bitemporal hemianopia

 

The lesion refers to a craniopharyngioma, a tumor that arises from the remnants of Rathke's pouch, located near the pituitary gland.

 

Craniopharyngiomas are commonly found near the optic chiasm, where the crossing of the nasal fibers of the optic nerves occurs. When this tumor grows, it can compress the optic chiasm, leading to bitemporal hemianopia. This condition results in the loss of peripheral vision in both eyes because the tumor specifically damages the nasal fibers, which are responsible for peripheral vision.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single vision field loss: Single vision field loss would occur with damage to the optic nerve on one side, not at the optic chiasm. Craniopharyngiomas typically affect both nasal fibers at the chiasm, leading to a specific pattern of vision loss, not confined to a single visual field.

 

Option C. Complete blindness: Complete blindness would require extensive damage to the entire visual pathway, which is not typical of craniopharyngioma unless the tumor has become exceptionally large and invasive. The usual presentation is partial vision loss, particularly affecting the peripheral fields.

 

Option D. Homonymous hemianopia: Homonymous hemianopia occurs when there is damage to the optic tract, lateral geniculate body, optic radiations, or occipital cortex on one side, leading to loss of the same visual field in both eyes. This pattern does not fit with craniopharyngioma, which specifically affects the optic chiasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopharyngiomas commonly cause bitemporal hemianopia due to compression of the optic chiasm, resulting in peripheral vision loss on both sides.

questions.text: Mrs. Patel is a 45-year-old woman who has recently been diagnosed with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Her doctor informs her that the cancer is hormone-dependent. The doctor recommends a treatment plan that includes surgery, radiation therapy, and hormone therapy. What is the drug used for estrogen dependent breast cancer? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tamoxifen

 

Explanation:

 

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used to treat hormone receptor-positive breast cancers, particularly in premenopausal women. It is effective for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer, which is hormone-dependent. Tamoxifen works by blocking the effects of estrogen in the breast tissue, thereby preventing cancer cells from growing and spreading.

  • Mechanism of Action: Tamoxifen competes with estrogen for binding to estrogen receptors in breast tissue. By blocking estrogen's effects, it inhibits the growth and proliferation of estrogen-dependent cancer cells.
  • Administration: Tamoxifen is taken orally, usually once a day for five years.
  • Side Effects: Common side effects include hot flashes, mood changes, vaginal dryness, and an increased risk of blood clots (DVT).

 

Uses of Tamoxifen:

  • Primary Prophylaxis: Used for the primary prophylaxis of breast cancer in high-risk women.
  • Risk Reduction: Reduces the risk of carcinoma in the contralateral breast.
  • Recurrence Prevention: Lowers the risk of recurrence of carcinoma in both ipsilateral and contralateral breasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estrogen: Estrogen is not used as a treatment for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer because it would promote cancer cell growth. In fact, therapies aim to reduce or block estrogen to prevent cancer progression.

 

Option B. Clomiphene citrate: Clomiphene citrate is a medication used to induce ovulation in women with fertility issues. It is not used in the treatment of breast cancer.

 

Option D. Adriamycin (Doxorubicin): Adriamycin is a chemotherapy drug used to treat various types of cancer, including breast cancer. It works by interfering with the DNA in cancer cells, preventing them from dividing and growing. While effective in some cancer treatments, it is not specifically used for hormone therapy in estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen is the drug used for treating estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer by blocking the effects of estrogen on breast tissue, thereby preventing the growth and spread of hormone-dependent cancer cells.

questions.text: A person who met with an accident, and suffered from a skull fracture presents with the following finding. Identify this clinical finding. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Battle sign

 

The image shows Battle's sign.

 

It is retroarticular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from fracture of middle cranial fossa following head trauma. Battle sign is prominent when there is a fracture of the petrous temporal bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection extends into the infratemporal fossa.

 

Option C: Mastoiditis presents as retro-auricular redness, swelling which is painful.

 

Option D: The Griesinger sign refers to edema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying the mastoid process as a result of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is a complication of acute otomastoiditis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Battle's sign is a significant diagnostic clue in trauma patients, signaling a possible basilar skull fracture. Recognition of this sign should prompt further diagnostic imaging and careful neurologic assessment to manage potential complications associated with such fractures.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition

questions.text: A patient, who consumed a large number of TCA pills during a depressive episode, presented with altered sensorium, hypotension, and wide QRS complexes on ECG. What is the next best step in treatment? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NAHCO3

 

A patient presenting with altered sensorium, hypotension, and wide QRS complexes on ECG following an overdose of tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) requires immediate treatment to address the cardiotoxic effects of the overdose. The best next step in this scenario is the administration of intravenous Sodium Bicarbonate (NAHCO3). Sodium Bicarbonate is used to treat the sodium channel blockade caused by TCAs, which is responsible for the wide QRS complexes. It works by alkalinizing the blood, which helps to mitigate the cardiotoxic effects of TCAs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DC Cardioversion: This is generally used for unstable patients with life-threatening arrhythmias. In the case of TCA overdose, the priority is to treat the underlying cause of the arrhythmia (the sodium channel blockade), which is more effectively addressed with sodium bicarbonate.

 

Option B. Start antiarrhythmic drug: The use of antiarrhythmic drugs may be risky in the setting of TCA overdose, as these medications can exacerbate the cardiotoxic effects of TCAs.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect because there is a clear and specific treatment indicated for this scenario, which is the administration of Sodium Bicarbonate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 644.

questions.text: A newly joined teacher develops rice water stools. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GM1 ganglioside receptor

 

The given clinical scenario of rice-water stools is suggestive of cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae. The toxin produced by the organism acts on GM1 ganglioside receptors.

 

Vibrio cholerae is a comma-shaped, gram-negative bacillus with darting motility. It has a single polar flagellum. It causes cholera, an acute diarrheal disease. It is marked by painless, profuse, watery diarrhea with flecks of mucus (rice water stools) associated with effortless vomiting. Pulmonary edema and arrhythmias are some of the complications.

 

Infection is acquired by ingestion of contaminated food and water. The organisms produce an enterotoxin known as cholera toxin (CT). It has 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B subunit (binding units) fixes to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on jejunal epithelial cells. The A subunit dissociates into the A2 fragment, which attaches the A1 fragment to the B subunit. This results in prolonged accumulation of cAMP, which causes an outpouring of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Ultimately, it results in profuse watery diarrhea.

 

In addition to the cholera toxin, additional toxins such as zona occludes toxin and accessory cholera toxin are also produced. The former alters intestinal permeability by its action on intestinal epithelial cells.

 

The characteristic darting mobility and its hindrance by antiserum can be used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.

 

Fluid resuscitation by rice-based ORS is recommended. Medical management includes erythromycin or azithromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GM2 ganglioside receptor: Not involved in the mechanism of cholera toxin.

 

Option C. Sphingomyelin: While it is a component of cell membranes, it is not the receptor for cholera toxin.

 

Option D. Cerebroganglioside: Also not a receptor for cholera toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding that cholera toxin acts on GM1 ganglioside receptors is crucial for grasping the pathophysiological basis of cholera. This interaction triggers a cascade of events leading to the massive, life-threatening secretory diarrhea that characterizes the disease. Proper hydration and antibiotics like erythromycin are key to treatment.

choices.text: A – Apocrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Eccrine sweat gland, D – Sebaceous gland
A – Arrector pilorum, B – Apocrine sweat gland, C – Eccrine sweat gland, D – Sebaceous gland
A – Sebaceous gland, B – Eccrine sweat gland, C – Arrector pilorum, D – Apocrine sweat gland
A – Eccrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Sebaceous gland, D – Apocrine sweat gland

questions.text: Which of the following correctly identifies the skin appendages labeled A to D in the given histological image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A – Eccrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Sebaceous gland, D – Apocrine sweat gland

 

In the image provided, several distinct structures of the skin are labeled:

 

A (Eccrine sweat gland): Eccrine sweat glands are small, coiled glands located superficially in the dermis. They are responsible for temperature regulation through sweat secretion. In the image, A is identified as the eccrine sweat gland, which appears closer to the skin surface compared to the apocrine gland.

 

B (Arrector pilorum): This is a small muscle attached to the hair follicle known as the arrector pilorum. It is responsible for causing hair to stand up during cold or emotional stress, leading to goosebumps.

 

C (Sebaceous gland): These glands are associated with hair follicles and secrete sebum, an oily substance that lubricates the skin and hair. In the image, C is correctly identified as the sebaceous gland.

 

D (Apocrine sweat gland): Apocrine sweat glands are located deeper in the dermis or hypodermis and are associated with hair follicles. They produce a thicker, milky secretion that contributes to body odor when broken down by bacteria. D is correctly labeled as the apocrine sweat gland, which is found deeper compared to eccrine glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eccrine sweat glands are located closer to the skin surface, arrector pilorum is a small muscle connected to hair follicles, sebaceous glands produce sebum and are linked to hair follicles, while apocrine sweat glands are deeper and secrete a thicker fluid associated with hair follicles.

questions.text: In which of the following analyses is monetary benefit quantified? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cost benefit analysis

 

Cost Benefit Analysis (CBA): CBA is a method used to evaluate the total costs versus the total benefits of a project or decision in monetary terms. It helps determine whether the benefits of a project or decision outweigh the costs, thereby justifying the investment. This type of analysis assigns a monetary value to all outcomes, allowing for a direct comparison between costs and benefits. For example, the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) might report that it saved $12 million in a given year.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cost Effective Analysis (CEA): Definition: CEA assesses the relative costs and outcomes (effects) of different courses of action.

 

  • Output: It is measured in non-monetary terms such as health outcomes (e.g., quality-adjusted life years (QALY) saved). For instance, the NTEP might measure its effectiveness by the number of lives saved or the improvement in the quality of life.

 

Option C. Network Analysis: Definition: This is a quantitative method that involves mapping out and analyzing the sequence of activities and events in a project.

 

  • Tools: It includes techniques like Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT) and Critical Path Method (CPM).
  • Usage: Network analysis is used to identify the sequence of tasks, the longest path through the project (critical path), and to optimize the project schedule.

 

Option D. Input Output Analysis: Definition: This method examines the relationship between inputs and outputs in an economic system.

 

  • Application: It can include both cost-benefit and cost-effective analyses as it calculates the effects of changing inputs on the outputs. This type of analysis is often used in economics to understand how different sectors of an economy interact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CBA [Cost Benefit Analysis] - Results of a program analyzed in terms of MONETARY benefits, e.g. NTEP (2023-24) saved 12 m US $

 

CEA [Cost Effective Analysis] - Output of a program analyzed in terms of RESULTS eg. NTEP (2023-24) save 1.7 Million people can be determined with help of QALY.

 

INPUT-OUTPUT ANALYSIS - Calculation of effects of changing the inputs (Includes CBA & CEA)

 

NETWORK ANALYSIS – It is a quantitative method. It includes activities & events. PERT is sequence of activities. CPM is the longest path in PERT.

choices.text: It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum
It can be confirmatory test of trisomy 13, 18 and 21
It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation
It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about non-invasive prenatal testing? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It can be confirmatory test of trisomy 13, 18 and 21

 

Explanation:

 

Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening tool, not a diagnostic tool. It uses cell-free fetal DNA circulating in the maternal serum to screen for certain genetic conditions, including trisomies 13, 18, and 21.

 

NIPT is not used for diagnosis but for screening. It has high sensitivity (about 99%) for detecting trisomies 21, 18, and 13, but positive results must be confirmed with diagnostic tests such as chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum: Correct. NIPT uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum to assess the risk of certain genetic conditions in the fetus.

 

Option C. It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation: Correct. NIPT can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation, when there is enough fetal DNA in the maternal blood for accurate analysis.

 

Option D. It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment: Correct. NIPT is often done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment, which helps determine gestational age and detect multiple pregnancies or major anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening test for aneuploidy using cell-free fetal DNA in maternal serum, typically performed after 10 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: Page 890, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital, with complaints of seizures and the MRI image of the brain is given below. The disease is most probably caused by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cysticercosis cellulose

 

The given clinical scenario and MRI brain showing scolex within multiple cystic lesions are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by the larval form of T. solium called Cysticercosis cellulose.

 

Neurocysticercosis is the most common central nervous system parasitic infection.

 

The clinical features of neurocysticercosis include:

 

  • ﻿﻿Epilepsy
  • ﻿﻿Increased intracranial tension
  • ﻿﻿Hydrocephalus
  • ﻿﻿Psychiatric disturbances
  • ﻿﻿Meningoencephalitis
  • ﻿﻿Transient paresis
  • ﻿﻿Behavioral disorders
  • ﻿﻿Aphasia
  • ﻿﻿Visual disturbances.

 

The CT and MRI findings seen in neurocysticercosis are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Scolex within a cyst
  • ﻿﻿Cystic lesions with or without ring enhancement
  • ﻿﻿Nodular calcifications
  • ﻿﻿Focal enhancing lesions
  • ﻿﻿Multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.

 

Note: About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis.

 

Albendazole is the drug of choice for neurocysticercosis. Glucocorticoid therapy is usually begun before initiating albendazole (antiparasitic drug). This is continued for several days after the institution of therapy to reduce the incidence of side effects from inflammatory reactions to dead and dying cysticerci of Taenia solium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T. saginata: Incorrect. Known as the beef tapeworm, it does not typically lead to cysticercosis as its larvae (Cysticercus bovis) primarily infect cattle.

 

Option C. Cysticercosis bovis: Incorrect. This term is not applicable to human disease and refers to the larval stage of T. saginata found in cattle.

 

Option D. T. asiatica: Incorrect. This is a species of tapeworm similar to T. saginata and is associated with pigs, but like T. saginata, it is not commonly linked to neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurocysticercosis is identified with imaging studies, particularly in patients presenting with new-onset seizures and specific MRI findings of cystic lesions with scolex, is critical for timely diagnosis and appropriate management, including antiparasitic and supportive therapy.

choices.text: Aschoff's bodies
Epithelioid granuloma
Granulomatous vasculitis

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with migratory arthritis and examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur. An echocardiography was performed which was suggestive of mitral regurgitation. A biopsy specimen was obtained and the image is provided below. What is the most likely lesion shown in the histopathology slide? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aschoff’s bodies

 

Acute rheumatic fever is suggested by the clinical findings of migratory arthritis, pan-systolic murmur, and mitral regurgitation. Aschoff's bodies are the most likely lesion in the histopathological slide.

 

Acute RF causes focal inflammatory lesions in a variety of tissues. Aschoff bodies are distinct lesions in the heart that consist of foci of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for RF). These macrophages have a lot of cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin in a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the name "caterpillar cells"), and they can get multinucleated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epithelioid granuloma: Epithelioid granulomas are associated with chronic inflammatory conditions such as tuberculosis or sarcoidosis. They do not have the characteristic Anitschkow cells seen in Aschoff bodies.

 

Option  C. Granulomatous vasculitis: Granulomatous vasculitis is characterized by granulomas in the walls of blood vessels, which is seen in conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis. It does not match the histological description of Aschoff bodies.

 

Option D. Granuloma inguinale: Granuloma inguinale, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, presents with genital ulcers and Donovan bodies on histology, which is unrelated to the cardiac findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aschoff bodies, which consist of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and characteristic Anitschkow cells, are the hallmark histological feature of acute rheumatic fever, a condition that can lead to significant cardiac involvement, including mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A child was born after 8 months of the father’s death. Grandparents filed a case that the baby might not be their son’s, but DNA came positive. What is such a child called? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posthumous child

 

A posthumous child is one who is born after the death of either parent. In this scenario, the child was born 8 months after the father's death, which fits the definition of a posthumous child. The grandparents doubted the child’s legitimacy, but DNA testing confirmed the biological connection, validating the child's status as the deceased father's offspring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suppositious child: A suppositious child is a term used to describe a fraudulent or fake child who is falsely presented as an heir, often to claim property or inheritance. This does not apply in this case because the DNA test confirmed the child’s legitimacy as the biological offspring.

 

Option B. Fictitious child: A fictitious child is purely an imaginary or invented figure that does not exist in reality, often found in literature or imagination. This term is unrelated to the case as it refers to nonexistent entities, unlike the real, biologically confirmed child in question.

 

Option D. Illegitimate child: An illegitimate child is one born outside of marriage or not legally recognized as belonging to the mother's husband. In this case, the DNA test confirmed that the child is indeed the biological offspring of the deceased father, making the term irrelevant here.

 

Educational Objective:


A posthumous child is one born after the death of a parent, as seen in this scenario where the child was born 8 months after the father's death.

questions.text: A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He has had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Giant papillary conjunctivitis

 

  • The clinical history of watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva, suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.
  • Giant papillary conjunctivitis is the inflammation of conjunctiva with formation of very large sized papillae.
  • Etiology - It is a localized allergic response to a physically rough or deposited surface (contact lens, prosthesis, left out nylon sutures).
  • Symptoms - Itching, stringy discharge and reduced wearing time of contact lens or prosthetic shell.
  • Signs - Papillary hypertrophy (1 mm in diameter) of the upper tarsal conjunctiva with hyperemia. Focal apical ulceration and whitish scarring may develop on larger papillae. Papillae are reddish, flat-topped, raised areas that give a red and velvety appearance to the tarsal conjunctiva.
  • Treatment:
    1. The offending cause should be removed. After discontinuation of contact lens or artificial eye or removal of nylon sutures, the papillae resolve over a period of one month.
    2. Disodium cromoglycate is known to relieve the symptoms and enhance the rate of resolution.
    3. Steroids are not of much use in this condition.

 

Other Options:

                                        

Option A. In acute trachoma, sago-like follicles are characteristically seen. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The SAFE strategy is used in the management of trachoma.

 

The image below shows sago-like follicles in trachoma.

 

 

Option B. It is an acute catarrhal conjunctivitis associated with marked follicular hyperplasia especially of the lower fornix and lower palpebral conjunctiva. Follicles are greyish-white raised areas on fornices and palpebral conjunctiva. These are formed due to the localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer. It is most commonly caused by herpes and adenoviruses.

 

The image shows follicles.

 

 

Option D. Spring catarrh is considered a hypersensitivity reaction to some exogenous allergen, such as grass pollens. It is more common during summer. Cobblestone appearance (which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva), ropy discharge, and Maxwell-Lyon sign are present. Horner-Trantas spots that are discrete, whitish, raised dots along the limbus can also be seen.

 

The image below shows Horner-Trantas spots.

 

 

Pseudogerontoxon - Pseudogerontoxon is a lesion that resembles a small segment of arcus senilis or gerontoxon and is seen in many individuals with limbal vernal or atopic keratoconjunctivitis. It is an important clinical finding because pseudogerontoxon is often times the only clinical evidence of previous allergic eye disease.

 

 

Shield Ulcer- Localized oval or pentagonal lesion in upper cornea.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is characterized by the presence of large papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, often due to a localized allergic response to contact lenses or other foreign bodies.

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with fatigue, tiredness and cervical lymphadenopathy. The TLC and DLC were normal. No immature cells. A lymph node biopsy was performed which shows diffuse effacement of the Lymph node architecture, cells with an indented nucleus, prominent nucleolus, and are atypical. CD10 and BCL2 are positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Follicular lymphoma

 

The clinical scenario presented here, which includes fatigue, tiredness, and cervical lymphadenopathy with CD10 positive BCL2 positive cells, strongly suggests follicular lymphoma.

 

The most common type of indolent NHL is follicular lymphoma. It usually appears in middle age and affects both men and women equally. The tumour is most likely caused by germinal centre B cells.

 

A (14;18) translocation between the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the BCL2 locus on chromosome 18 is the hallmark of follicular lymphoma.

 

Histologically, at low magnification, a predominantly nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern is observed in involved lymph nodes. Two principal cell types are present in varying proportions: (1) small cells with irregular or cleaved nuclear contours and scant cytoplasm, referred to as centrocytes (small cleaved cells); and (2) larger cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm, referred to as centroblasts.

 

Immunophenotyping - The neoplastic cells closely resemble normal germinal center B cells, expressing CD19, CD20, CD10, surface Ig, and BCL6. CD5 is not expressed. BCL2 is expressed in more than 90% of cases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Burkitt Lymphoma: Typically presents with a high-grade lymphoma and a starry sky pattern on histology. It is associated with c-MYC translocation and does not usually express BCL2.

 

Option C. Mycosis Fungoides: A type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma that presents with skin lesions and does not typically show CD10 or BCL2 positivity.

 

Option D. Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML): Characterized by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL fusion gene) and presents with marked leukocytosis and often splenomegaly, not with lymphadenopathy and histological findings as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular lymphoma is characterized by diffuse effacement of lymph node architecture, cells with indented nuclei and prominent nucleoli, and positive immunophenotyping for CD10 and BCL2. It typically presents in middle-aged individuals with symptoms such as fatigue, tiredness, and lymphadenopathy. The presence of the t(14;18) translocation involving BCL2 is a hallmark of this indolent non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A patient is confused, opens his eyes on painful stimuli, flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. His Glasgow Coma Score is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 11

 

The GCS in this patient is 11.

  • The score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused.
  • The score for eye-opening: 2, because his eyes are opening to only painful stimulus.
  • The score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize pain. Though he also flexes on one side (M4), the higher response is counted in GCS.

Therefore, the GCS score is (4+2+5) = 11

 

 

Educational Objective:


The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is calculated based on eye response, verbal response, and motor response, with a total score indicating the level of consciousness.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for an overactive bladder in a patient with dementia? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Tolterodine

 

Tolterodine is an anticholinergic drug that is specifically used for treating symptoms of overactive bladder, such as frequent urination, urgency, and incontinence. It works by inhibiting the action of acetylcholine on muscarinic receptors in the bladder, which reduces bladder contractions and helps manage overactive bladder symptoms.

 

In patients with dementia, particularly Alzheimer's disease, the use of anticholinergic medications like tolterodine can be concerning because they can potentially exacerbate cognitive decline due to their effects on the central nervous system. However, tolterodine remains a common treatment option when managing overactive bladder in such patients, especially when other options are limited.

 

Remember –

 

Most appropriate treatment for an overactive bladder in a patient with dementia:

 

Mirabegron >> Trospium (as it has minimal CNS entry) >> Tolterodine

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tiotropium: Tiotropium is an anticholinergic drug used as a long-acting inhalational bronchodilator in the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and asthma. It is not used for treating overactive bladder.

 

Option C. Telenzepine: Telenzepine is a selective M1 muscarinic receptor antagonist used in the treatment of peptic ulcers by reducing gastric acid secretion. It is not indicated for the treatment of overactive bladder.

 

Option D. Tropicamide: Tropicamide is an anticholinergic drug used as an eye drop to induce mydriasis (pupil dilation) and cycloplegia for eye examinations. It is not used for overactive bladder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tolterodine is an appropriate treatment for overactive bladder, but caution is needed in dementia patients due to its anticholinergic properties, which can potentially worsen cognitive function. When selecting an anticholinergic drug for these patients, those with minimal CNS penetration, like trospium, would be preferable if available.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presented with complaints of diarrhea and foul-smelling stool. His stool microscopy did not show any ova or eggs, but there was the presence of motile 200 μm larva. Identify the organism. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The Ans.  is Strongyloides stercoralis because this organism is known for producing motile larvae rather than eggs in the stool, which aligns with the findings in this patient. Strongyloides stercoralis is unique among the listed options in that it is ovoviviparous: it produces eggs that hatch into larvae inside the host. This explains why motile larvae, rather than eggs or ova, are observed in stool microscopy.

 

This characteristic is crucial for distinguishing Strongyloides from other helminths, particularly in immunocompromised patients like those with HIV, where the infection can become disseminated and more severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma duodenale: This organism typically shows eggs, not larvae, in stool samples. It is a type of hookworm, and its diagnostic stage involves eggs rather than motile larvae.

 

Option B. Ascaris lumbricoides: Ascaris is diagnosed by finding eggs in the stool, not larvae. It is a large roundworm whose diagnostic stage in stool is the presence of characteristic eggs.

 

Option C. Schistosoma mansoni: Schistosoma species are identified by the presence of characteristic eggs in stool or urine, depending on the species. Motile larvae are not seen in stool samples for Schistosoma infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strongyloides stercoralis is diagnosed by the presence of motile larvae in stool, distinguishing it from other helminths that typically show eggs in stool samples.

questions.text: Which medication is considered the drug of choice for Benign Rolandic Epilepsy? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Sodium Valproate

 

Explanation:

 

Benign Rolandic Epilepsy, also known as Benign Childhood Epilepsy with Centrotemporal Spikes (BECTS), is one of the most common childhood epilepsy syndromes. Sodium valproate is considered the drug of choice for this condition due to its broad spectrum antiepileptic properties and effectiveness in controlling both partial and generalized seizures. It works by increasing brain levels of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), an inhibitory neurotransmitter.

 

Benign Rolandic Epilepsy typically presents with focal seizures involving the face, particularly during sleep, and has a characteristic EEG pattern with centrotemporal spikes. The condition is self-limiting and generally resolves by adolescence, but antiepileptic therapy may be needed during the active phase.
