Other Options:

 

Option A. Gabapentin - Incorrect. While gabapentin is used as an anticonvulsant, it is not the first-line therapy for Benign Rolandic Epilepsy. It is more commonly used for neuropathic pain and as adjunctive therapy for partial seizures.

 

Option C. Barbiturates - Incorrect. Barbiturates are older generation antiepileptic drugs with significant side effects including sedation and cognitive impairment. They are rarely used as first-line therapy for childhood epilepsies today.

 

Option D. Phenytoin - Incorrect. Phenytoin is primarily effective against generalized tonic-clonic and partial seizures but is not the drug of choice for Benign Rolandic Epilepsy due to its side effect profile and pharmacokinetic variability in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium valproate is the preferred first-line treatment for Benign Rolandic Epilepsy due to its efficacy and relatively favorable side effect profile compared to other antiepileptic medications in children.

choices.text: Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel
Shift to OT, start IV antibiotics, and pack the tonsillar fossa
Give anticoagulants, repeated gargling, and wait for 24 hours
Do blood transfusion and wait and watch

questions.text: A patient post-tonsillectomy in the recovery room starts bleeding from the operative site. On examination, blood clots are seen. What will be your immediate management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel

 

The given clinical picture is suggestive of reactionary hemorrhage post-tonsillectomy and the immediate management is to shift the patient to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the bleeding vessel.

 

Hemorrhage is a common complication of tonsillectomy. It can be primary, reactionary, or secondary:

 

  • Primary hemorrhage occurs at the time of operation. It can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.
  • Reactionary hemorrhage occurs within 24 hours. It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or blood pressure returning to normal. It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor. Ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels is done under anesthesia if the above measures fail.
  • Secondary hemorrhage is usually seen between the 5th to 10th postoperative day. It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane. Removal of the clot, topical application of dilute adrenaline or hydrogen peroxide with pressure usually suffice. IV antibiotics are given and the bleeding vessel is electro coagulated or ligated if bleeding continues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate return to the OT for direct intervention is essential in managing post-tonsillectomy bleeding. Ensuring the bleeding vessel is adequately addressed through cauterization or ligation can prevent further complications and promote healing.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 504, 505

choices.text: Divalent Metal Transporter 1
Divalent Metal Transporter 2

questions.text: What is the transporter of iron into enterocytes? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Divalent Metal Transporter 1

 

Explanation

 

Iron uptake into enterocytes is primarily facilitated by the Divalent Metal Transporter 1 (DMT1), which actively transports ferrous iron (Fe2+) across the apical membrane of these cells. The process involves several steps:

 

  1. Reduction of Iron: Luminal non-heme iron, predominantly in the ferric (Fe3+) state, must first be reduced to ferrous (Fe2+) iron. This reduction is carried out by ferrireductases like b cytochromes and STEAP3.
  2. Transport via DMT1: Once reduced to Fe2+, iron is transported into the enterocytes through DMT1 located on the apical membrane.
  3. Exit from Enterocytes: After crossing into the enterocyte, Fe2+ destined for the circulation is exported across the basolateral membrane by Ferroportin. This export is coupled with the oxidation of Fe2+ back to Fe3+ by iron oxidases such as hephaestin and ceruloplasmin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferroportin 1: Incorrect as Ferroportin is responsible for the export of iron from enterocytes into the blood, not for iron uptake into enterocytes.

 

Option B. Hephaestin: Incorrect because hephaestin is involved in the oxidation of Fe2+ to Fe3+ during iron export from enterocytes, not in the uptake.

 

Option D. Divalent Metal Transporter 2: Incorrect as DMT2 is not the primary transporter involved in the uptake of iron into enterocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Divalent Metal Transporter 1 (DMT1) is critical for the uptake of ferrous iron (Fe2+) into enterocytes from the intestinal lumen, functioning in conjunction with enzymes that reduce ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) iron.

questions.text: Which nerve supplies the hybrid muscle partially spared in a patient who presented with sciatica and tender hamstrings? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obturator nerve

 

The adductor magnus is a hybrid muscle in the medial compartment of the thigh, which is partially spared in cases of sciatica due to its dual nerve supply. The adductor magnus has two heads: the ischial head (hamstring part) and the pubic head (adductor part). The adductor part is supplied by the obturator nerve, while the hamstring part is supplied by the tibial component of the sciatic nerve. In patients with sciatica, the obturator nerve can still supply the adductor part of the adductor magnus, leading to partial sparing of muscle function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common peroneal nerve: This nerve supplies muscles in the anterior and lateral compartments of the leg and does not innervate the adductor magnus or any muscles in the medial thigh.

 

Option B. Femoral nerve: This nerve primarily supplies the anterior compartment of the thigh, including muscles like the quadriceps femoris, and does not innervate the adductor magnus.

 

Option D. Tibial nerve: Although the tibial nerve supplies the hamstring part of the adductor magnus, it is affected in sciatica, leading to the involvement of muscles it innervates, unlike the obturator nerve which partially spares the muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Quick revision of the hybrid muscles of the upper and lower limbs:

choices.text: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery
Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery
DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the flaps used in breast reconstruction?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DIEP is a myocutaneous flap

 

Explanation:

 

The Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator (DIEP) flap is a type of breast reconstruction flap that is derived from the deep inferior epigastric artery. The DIEP flap is a muscle-sparing flap, meaning it involves only the removal of skin, fat, and blood vessels (perforators), without taking any of the rectus abdominis muscle. This reduces the risk of post-operative abdominal weakness and complications, unlike the Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous (TRAM) flap, which includes muscle. Therefore, it is incorrect to refer to the DIEP flap as a myocutaneous flap because it does not include muscle.

 

DIEP is a myocutaneous flap: This statement is false. A myocutaneous flap includes muscle tissue, whereas the DIEP flap spares the rectus abdominis muscle, utilizing only the skin, fat, and perforator vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery: The pedicled TRAM flap stands for Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous flap. It relies on the superior epigastric artery for blood supply, which remains attached (pedicled) to its original source. The flap, including the rectus muscle, is tunneled under the skin to the chest to reconstruct the breast. This statement is accurate.

 

Option B. Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery: The free TRAM flap involves the removal of a section of the abdominal tissue, including the rectus muscle, along with the inferior epigastric arteries. This flap is transplanted to the chest and connected to the chest's blood vessels using microsurgical techniques. This flap utilizes both the superior and inferior epigastric arteries. This statement is accurate.

 

Option C. DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery: The DIEP flap is similar to the free TRAM flap but does not involve the removal of the rectus muscle. Instead, it uses only the skin, fat, and perforator blood vessels based on the deep inferior epigastric artery. This design spares the abdominal muscles, reducing post-operative complications. This statement is accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The DIEP flap is a muscle-sparing flap used in breast reconstruction, involving the skin, fat, and blood vessels without including muscle tissue, which differentiates it from a myocutaneous flap like the TRAM flap.

questions.text: The given image shows what grade of placenta previa? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) III

 

Explanation:

 

The image illustrates Type 3 placenta previa where the placenta partially covers the internal os. This classification is part of the older classification system known as Browne’s classification.

 

Placenta previa is categorized into different types based on how much the placenta covers the internal os of the cervix:

 

Older Classification (Browne’s classification):

 

  • Type 1: The lower edge of the placenta enters the lower segment but is away from the os.
  • Type 2: The placenta reaches the margin of the os but doesn’t cover it.
  • Type 3: The placenta partially covers the internal os (when fully dilated, it doesn’t cover).
  • Type 4: The placenta completely covers the os.

 

Newer Classification (based on Transvaginal Sonography - TVS; by ACOG):

 

  1. True Placenta Previa: The placenta covers the internal os.
  2. Low-lying Placenta: The placenta lies within 2 cm of the internal os but does not cover it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV: This would mean the placenta completely covers the os, which is not the case in the given image.

 

Option C. II: This would mean the placenta reaches the margin of the os but does not cover it, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Option D. I: This would mean the lower edge of the placenta enters the lower segment but is away from the os, which does not align with the given image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta previa is classified based on the extent to which the placenta covers the internal os, with Type 3 indicating partial coverage.

 

Types of Placentae previa

 

Older Classification (Browne’s classification)

 

 

 

Newer Classification (based on Transvaginal Sonography -TVS); By ACOG

 

  1. True Placenta Previa: Placenta covers the internal os
  2. Low lying placenta: Placenta lies within 2 cm of the internal os but does not cover it. 

 

Ref: Page 658, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately
Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours

questions.text: A 2-year-old toddler with a weight of 11 kg was brought to the pediatric outpatient department. The child exhibited a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute and upon examination, noticeable chest indrawing was detected. What is the next step of management? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Oral amoxicillin for five days

 

According to the latest revised guidelines by WHO, the management of childhood pneumonia has been updated based on new evidence. In the given scenario, a 2-year-old child presents with a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute and chest indrawing, which fits the criteria for pneumonia but without general danger signs. According to the revised classification, the appropriate management for this case is oral amoxicillin for five days and home care advice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately: This is recommended for children showing general danger signs or very severe disease, not for pneumonia with chest indrawing without other danger signs.

 

Option C. Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours: This would be applicable for severe cases requiring inpatient care, not for managing a case of pneumonia without general danger signs at an outpatient department.

 

Option D. Start antipyretics urgently: While antipyretics may be used to manage fever, they do not address the underlying pneumonia and are not the primary management step in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is involved in the hyperacute rejection of renal transplants? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type II

 

Hyperacute graft rejection is an example of type II hypersensitivity reaction.

 

It is mediated by preformed antibodies. It is a rare event that occurs in kidney transplantation.

 

This results in rapid, severe, and often irreversible damage to the transplanted kidney, leading to graft failure. The preformed antibodies are usually directed against specific antigens on the endothelial cells of the donor organ.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type IV: Incorrect, Type IV hypersensitivity is a delayed reaction mediated by T cells, not antibodies, and is not responsible for hyperacute rejection.

 

Option B. Type III: Incorrect, Type III hypersensitivity involves immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) that can deposit in tissues and cause inflammation but is not the mechanism behind hyperacute rejection.

 

Option D. Type I: Incorrect, Type I hypersensitivity is an immediate allergic reaction (like asthma or anaphylaxis) mediated by IgE antibodies, which is different from the antibody-mediated attack on transplanted organs seen in hyperacute rejection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type II hypersensitivity is crucial in the context of hyperacute rejection of renal transplants, highlighting the importance of thorough pre-transplant screening for donor-specific antibodies to avoid this rapid and destructive immune response.

choices.text: Bipartite patella; X-ray of other knee

questions.text: Shown below is an X-ray of a patient with history of a chronic knee pain. True statement concerning the X-ray shown would be: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bipartite patella; X-ray other knee

 

BIPARTITE PATELLA

 

  • It is the congenital fragmentation of patella.
  • In this condition, the patella is made up of two separate bones instead of one.
  • It occurs when the patella fails to fuse properly during development, leading to a bipartite appearance.
  • This condition is typically asymptomatic and may go unnoticed for many years.
  • In some cases, it can cause pain, swelling, or discomfort, especially during physical activity.
  • The X-ray of opposite knee must be taken as the condition is bilateral in 50% of cases and this condition is more common in males than females.

 

 

  • Management usually involves conservative measures to alleviate symptoms like rest, ice, and physical therapy to strengthen the Quadriceps muscles, and reduce stress on the patella.
  • In more severe cases, a brace may be recommended to provide additional support and reduce stress on the patella.
  • Pain medications and anti-inflammatory drugs may also be prescribed to relieve pain and reduce inflammation.
  • If conservative measures fail to provide relief, surgery may be considered. Surgery typically involves removing the smaller bone fragment and smoothing the joint surface to reduce friction and alleviate pain.
  • In rare cases, surgery may involve fusing the two patellar fragments together to create a single patella.
  • With appropriate treatment, most people can return to their normal activities without significant limitations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avulsion fracture; cylindrical cast. In avulsion fracture of PCL alone, the non-operative treatment relies on restoration of tibiofemoral relationship with immobilization, followed by physiotherapy. In the first 6 weeks, immobilization and limited weight bearing is achieved using a cylindrical cast in 15° flexion or with posterior support in the form of extension or dynamic anterior drawer brace to prevent subluxation of tibia.

 

 

Option C. Avulsion fracture; wire fixation. K-wire fixation is done for distal phalanx base avulsion fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows bipartite patella which is a congenital fragmentation of patella i.e., the patella is made of two separate bones instead of one.
  • In this condition, it is always recommended to get an x-ray of the other knee also as this condition is bilateral in most cases.
  • It is treated by surgical removal of the smaller bone fragment when the conservative methods fail to provide relief.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with abdominal distension, jaundice, and pruritis. Ascitic fluid analysis revealed a neutrophil count > 650 per cubic mm. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis

 

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is a common and serious complication in patients with chronic liver disease and ascites. It is diagnosed when the ascitic fluid neutrophil count exceeds 250 cells/mm3. In this case, the neutrophil count is significantly higher than the threshold, indicating a strong likelihood of SBP.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Chronic Liver Disease Symptoms: The patient presents with symptoms typical of chronic liver disease, including abdominal distension, jaundice, and pruritis.
  • Neutrophil Count: An ascitic fluid neutrophil count > 250 cells/mm3 is diagnostic of SBP. This patient's count of > 650 cells/mm3 strongly supports this diagnosis.
  • Management: Immediate antibiotic therapy is crucial for SBP. Standard treatment involves third-generation cephalosporins like cefotaxime or ceftriaxone. In areas with high resistance to these antibiotics, piperacillin-tazobactam used in India.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant Ascites: Malignant ascites is associated with peritoneal carcinomatosis or other cancers. The neutrophil count in ascitic fluid in such cases is generally lower, and the fluid is often exudative rather than the neutrophil-predominant fluid seen in SBP.

 

Option C. Tubercular Ascites: Tubercular ascites usually presents with a lymphocyte-predominant fluid rather than neutrophil-predominant. It is also associated with other findings such as a high protein content and a positive acid-fast bacilli smear.

 

Option D. Intestinal Obstruction: Intestinal obstruction may lead to ascites, but the fluid analysis would not typically show a high neutrophil count. The clinical presentation and history would also differ significantly, focusing more on obstructive symptoms like severe pain, vomiting, and constipation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis should be suspected in patients with chronic liver disease and ascites if the ascitic fluid neutrophil count exceeds 250 cells/mm3, necessitating prompt antibiotic treatment.

questions.text: A pregnant woman comes to the clinic. She already has twins by normal delivery. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G2P1

 

In obstetric history, gravida (G) refers to the number of pregnancies a woman has had, including the current pregnancy, regardless of the outcome or duration. Parity (P) refers to the number of pregnancies that have reached the period of viability (28 weeks in India). Each pregnancy is counted once, regardless of the number of fetuses (e.g., twins count as one pregnancy).

 

  • Gravida (G): Number of pregnancies, including the current one.
  • Parity (P): Number of pregnancies that have reached viability (28 weeks or more), not including the current pregnancy.

 

In this case:

 

  • The woman has had one previous pregnancy that resulted in the birth of twins.
  • She is currently pregnant with her second pregnancy.

 

Therefore, her obstetric score is:

 

  • G2 (Gravida 2): This is her second pregnancy.
  • P1 (Para 1): She has had one previous pregnancy that reached viability and resulted in the birth of twins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G3P2: This would imply she has had three pregnancies and two that reached viability, which is incorrect.

 

Option B. G3P1: This would imply she is in her third pregnancy, which is incorrect.

 

Option D. G2P2: This would imply she has had two previous pregnancies that reached viability, which is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In obstetric scoring, twin pregnancies count as a single gravida, and the obstetric score for a woman with twins by normal delivery and currently pregnant should be G2P1.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The child's parents mention that the pain has been increasing over the past few hours. On examination, the child appears distressed and has abdominal tenderness. An X-ray is ordered, and it reveals a gasless abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Acute Pancreatitis

 

  • A gasless abdomen is seen in acute pancreatitis.
  • Acute pancreatitis is an inflammation of the pancreas, which can be caused by gallstones, alcohol consumption, and other factors. It can lead to severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, and increased heart rate. A gasless abdomen is seen in acute pancreatitis. Other signs include sentinel loop, renal halo and colon cut-off.
  • Other causes of gasless abdomen on Xray include:
    • A paucity of small bowel gas may be a normal finding in some adults
    • Bowel ischemia
    • Intestinal atresia
    • Ascites
    • Gastroenteritis
    • Large abdominal mass - due to displacement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulcerative Colitis: Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease that affects the innermost lining of the large intestine (colon) and rectum. Symptoms include diarrhea, often with blood or pus, abdominal pain, and rectal pain. In children, it may affect growth. A gasless abdomen on X-ray is not a typical feature of ulcerative colitis.

 

Option B. Intussusception: Intussusception is a condition in which a segment of the intestine "telescopes" into another, leading to bowel obstruction. This can cut off the blood supply to the affected portion of the intestine. It is one of the most common abdominal emergencies affecting children under two. Classic symptoms include intermittent abdominal pain, "currant jelly" stools, and a palpable "sausage-shaped" mass in the abdomen. While it can lead to changes in an abdominal X-ray like dilated small bowel loops, a gasless abdomen is not the primary diagnostic feature of intussusception.

 

Option D. Crohn's Disease: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from mouth to anus. Symptoms can include abdominal pain, severe diarrhea, fatigue, weight loss, and malnutrition. Inflammation caused by Crohn's disease can involve different areas of the digestive tract in different people. Unlike acute pancreatitis, a gasless abdomen is not a primary feature seen with Crohn's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A gasless abdomen on X-ray is commonly associated with acute pancreatitis in children presenting with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. This condition should be considered when evaluating similar clinical presentations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with chest pain, dyspnea increasing on lying down and relieved on sitting upright. On examination, heart sounds are muffled and her lungs are clear. CXR given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cardiac Tamponade

 

The patient's presentation and findings are indicative of cardiac tamponade. Cardiac tamponade occurs when fluid accumulates in the pericardial sac, compressing the heart and impairing its ability to pump effectively. This condition can result from various causes, including pericarditis, malignancy, trauma, or post-myocardial infarction.

 

Key features supporting cardiac tamponade:

 

  1. Chest pain and dyspnea: These symptoms can worsen when lying down and improve when sitting up, a condition known as orthopnea.
  2. Muffled heart sounds: Due to the fluid in the pericardial sac, the heart sounds are dampened.
  3. Clear lungs: This helps differentiate from pulmonary causes of dyspnea.
  4. Enlarged cardiac silhouette on CXR: The chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette, indicative of pericardial effusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Pulmonary edema: This condition typically presents with bilateral crackles on lung auscultation and possibly a history of heart failure. The chest X-ray would show features like Kerley B lines, pleural effusions, or alveolar edema, which are absent in this case.

 

Option B. Acute Pulmonary embolism: This can present with dyspnea and chest pain, but the ECG findings and clear lung fields on auscultation are less supportive. Additionally, acute pulmonary embolism typically does not cause an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

 

Option C. Acute MI (Myocardial Infarction): While acute MI can present with chest pain and dyspnea, it usually does not result in muffled heart sounds or an enlarged cardiac silhouette. Acute MI would more likely present with changes on ECG and possibly signs of heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac tamponade presents with symptoms of chest pain and dyspnea that worsen when lying down and improve when sitting up, muffled heart sounds, clear lung fields, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette on CXR.
